revision.text:
'''Te Moemoea no Iotefa''' was the first exhibition held in a civic art gallery in New Zealand focused on contemporary Pacific art.{{cite book|last1=Brunt|first1=Peter|last2=Nicholas|first2=Thomas|title=Art in Oceania : a new history|date=2013|publisher=Thames and Hudson|location=London|isbn=0500239010}}{{Rp|431}} ==Exhibition== The exhibition was curated by art historian Rangihiroa Panoho for the [[Sarjeant Art Gallery]] in [[Whanganui]] in 1990 and the metropolitan City Galleries in Wellington and in Auckland in 1991.{{cite web|last1=Abadia|first1=Karina|title=Maori Art Book Takes Inclusive Approach|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/books/69254057/maori-art-book-takes-inclusive-approach|website=Stuff.co.nz|accessdate=20 June 2015|date=18 June 2015}} It's starting point and its iconic motif was a Tahitian tivaevae featuring the Genesis story of the 'Dream of Joseph' or ''Te moemoea no Iotefa''. The exhibition initially filled all spaces of the historic Sarjeant Gallery building, an earlier version of the Wellington City Art Gallery and the entire first floor of the Auckland Art Gallery.{{cite book|last1=Panoho|first1=Rangihiroa|title=Te Moemoea no Iotefa (The dream of Joseph)|date=1990|publisher=Sarjeant Art Gallery|location=Whanganui}} In the exhibition catalogue Panoho outlined the South Pacific as, 'Aotearoa's most immediate historical, geographical and cultural context', and that he was seeking to 'examine and explore the visual side of this context and the ways in which artists in this country are exploring it'. The exhibition brought together four strands of art making:
1. The wealth of material culture from the Pacific Islands found in museums, libraries, private collections - [[taonga]] such as historical writing, photographs, [[tapa cloth|tapa]], tivaevae, weaving and carving. 2. Work currently being produced by Pacific Islanders living in New Zealand such as tivaevae and carving. 3. Work by [[palagi]] artists in this country (e.g. [[Tony Fomison|Fomison]], Shepherd, [[Vivian Lynn|Lynn]], [[Barry Lett Galleries|Lett]], [[Pat Hanly|Hanly]], McMillan, Adams, and Jowitt) which constitutes a response to Pacific Island subject and motif. 4. Work by contemporary Pacific artists utilising a Western aesthetic - to draw on and interpret their particular island cultures.
The exhibition 'wove together the various aspects of Pacific culture as it persists in Aotearoa'.{{cite book|last1=Chiu|first1=Melissa|last2=Stevenson|first2=Karen|last3=Mason|first3=Ngahiraka|last4=Vercoe|first4=Caroline|title=Paradise now? : contemporary art from the Pacific|date=2004|publisher=David Bateman in association with Asia Society|location=Auckland|isbn=1869535847}}{{Rp|24}} Art historian Nicholas Thomas writes 'Museum artifacts were placed with contemporary art, folk crafts with paintings, archive photographs with contemporary images, and Pacific artists among white appropriators of culture'.{{cite journal|last1=Thomas|first1=Nicholas|title=The Dream of Joseph: Practices of Identity in Pacific Art|journal=The Contemporary Pacific|date=1996|volume=8|issue=2|page=308}} The exhibition catalogue contains interviews with 10 contemporary artists included in the show: *Iosefa Leo *[[Fatu Feu'u]] *Jim Vivieaere *[[Lily Laita]] *[[John Pule]] *[[Michel Tuffery]] *Johnny Peninsula *[[Ioane Ioane]] *Sale Jessop *[[Sopolemalama Filipe Tohi|Filipe Tohi]] Te Moemoea was also an exploration of Pacificness as it more diversely related to broader creative activity in Aotearoa. As curator Panoho was not exclusively looking at contemporary Pacific art. As with his show 'Whatu Aho Rua' (1989/1992 - another Sarjeant exhibition involving historical and contemporary material) he was also interested in historical Pacific collections of tapa, fibre, photography and carving and in how non-Pacific artists were working with Pacific communities and in how they were interpreting the material and the ideas that they valorised. Te Moemoea while initiated from within a regional institution travelled to and was reinvented by Panoho and gallery staff within the Whanganui, Wellington and Auckland gallery spaces. A newspaper review from Wellington helps clarify the complexity and the layered nature of the content within Te Moemoea: '''Cross-currents crackle around the latest exhibition at Wellington's City Gallery. People who like to keep art in neat pigeonholes... will probably find '''Te Moemoea no Iotefa''' (Joseph's dream defeats them. Rangihīroa Panoho...has curated a lively exhibition which aims to be a lot more than a showcase for artists with a Pacific Island background who are working in New Zealand. It is that, but it's also a visual essay about cross-fertilisation''.' {{Cite web|url=https://pihirau.co.nz/maori-curator-ii-future-flowerings/|title=Margot Porter, 'Visual Essays of the Pacific', The Dominion, 20 July 1991|last=|first=|date=|website=Pihirau Productions Ltd|publisher=Pihirau|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-02}} '''' ==Reception and influence== ''Te Moemoea no Iotefa'' has been described as 'the first group exhibition to celebrate the dynamism of Pacific art'.{{cite book|last1=Raymond|first1=Rosanna|last2=Salmond|first2=Amiria|title=Pasifika Styles|date=2008|publisher=University of Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology; Otago University Press|location=Cambridge and Dunedin|isbn=0947595155}}{{Rp|40}} Pacific art historian Peter Brunt saw '''''Te Moemoea''''' as, '''The first exhibition to focus on contemporary Pacific art in a civic gallery in New Zealand was Te Moemoea no Iotefa '[the Dream of Joseph: A Celebration of Pacific Art and Taonga]...The exhibition thematized the presence of Pacific culture in New Zealand society, introduced community-based arts like tivaevae into the contemporary gallery, and canvassed the work of migrant artists like Fatu Feu'u, Johnny Penisula, Michel Tuffery and others, only then beginning to garner serious public attention. But it was the title that was the most prescient about its own historical significance. The title was borrowed from the title of a tivaevae it showed, and refers to the biblical story of Joseph sold into slavery in Egypt by his brothers, eventually to rise to a position of power in the Pharoah's court. Joseph's dream turns out to be an allegory of the moment of recognition when, as an exile, he reveals himself to his brothers as the important person he has become. The ambiguity of the allegory lies in the question of whether recognition in Egypt or escape from Egypt (if we can pardon the Orientalism) is the preferable goal''.' {{Cite web|url=https://pihirau.co.nz/maori-curator-ii-future-flowerings/|title=Art in Oceania|last=Brunt|first=Peter|date=2012|website=Pihirau Productions Ltd|publisher=Thames and Hudson|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 July 2018}} The exhibition contributed to a sense of group identification amongst a group of young or emerging artists, including Ioane, Tuffery, Laita and [[John Pule]].{{cite book|last1=Mallon|first1=Sean|last2=Pereira|first2=Pandora Fulimalo|title=Speaking in colour : conversations with artists of Pacific Island heritage|date=1997|publisher=Te Papa Press|location=Wellington|isbn=0909010447}}{{Rp|134}}The exhibition is seen as an important precursor to [[Bottled Ocean]], a 1994 exhibition focused on the work of contemporary Pacific artists.{{Rp|432}} Art historian Karen Stevenson notes the importance of the exhibition in building the careers of participating artists:
With the success of ''Te Moemoea no Iotefa'', Pacific artists found exhibition space more readily available, and as recognition of Pacific artists grew, dealer galleries and community centers became interested in hosting "Pacific" exhibitions. Group "Pacific" shows became regular occurrences in art galleries throughout the country, as did solo exhibitions at dealer galleries."{{Rp|25}}
== References== {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Indigenous art]] [[Category:1990 in New Zealand]] [[Category:Art exhibitions]] [[Category:Art exhibitions in New Zealand]]

{{Infobox album | name = The Masked Marauders | type = studio | artist = The Masked Marauders | cover = Masked Marauders.JPG | alt = | released = November 1969 | recorded = October 1969 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | length = 33:39 | label = [[Reprise Records|Reprise]]/Deity (Original)
[[Rhino Records|Rhino]] (Re-release) | producer = Deity Records | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Singles | name = | type = | single1 = Cow Pie / I Can't Get No Nookie | single1date = November 1969 }} }} {{Album ratings |rev1 = [[Allmusic]] |rev1Score = {{Rating|1.5|5}} {{Allmusic|class=album|id=r44197}} }} '''''The Masked Marauders''''' is a [[record album]] released on the [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros]] Reprise/Deity label in the fall of 1969 that was part of an elaborate [[hoax]] concocted by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine.{{cite news|last=Noth|first=Pierre Rene|title=Hoax Masked by Rock Record|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KwMqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PCgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4060,1901327&dq=the-masked-marauders+hoax&hl=en|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=December 24, 1969}}{{cite news|title=Were you a believer in The Masked Marauders?|url=http://rockcenter.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/05/17622557-were-you-a-believer-in-the-masked-marauders?lite|newspaper=NBC News|date=April 5, 2013}}{{cite web | last = Christgau | first = Robert | authorlink = Robert Christgau | title = Album of the Year | date = 1970-01-08 | url = http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/rock/album-70.php | accessdate = 2008-04-15}} In its October 18, 1969 issue, ''Rolling Stone'' ran a tongue-in-cheek [[review]] of a non-existent album that purportedly captured a "super session" of the era's leading [[rock and roll]] musicians, including [[Bob Dylan]], [[Mick Jagger]], [[John Lennon]], and [[Paul McCartney]]. The review claimed that none of the artists could be listed on the jacket cover because of contractual agreements with their recording companies. The editors involved decided to extend the joke by hiring a relatively obscure band to record an actual album and then secured a deal with Warner Bros. As an indication of how many people were taken in by the joke, ''The Masked Marauders'' reached No. 114 on ''[[Billboard 200|Billboard]]'s'' album chart. ==''Rolling Stone'' spoof== ''The Masked Marauders'' began as a spoof dreamed up by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' editor [[Greil Marcus]]. Under the [[pseudonym]] T.M. Christian (a reference to [[Terry Southern]]’s novel ''[[The Magic Christian (novel)|The Magic Christian]]''), Marcus wrote a satiric review of a fictitious double [[bootleg recording|bootleg]] album in collaboration with record reviewer Bruce Miroff.{{cite web | last = Marcus | first = Greil | authorlink = Greil Marcus | title = Online Exchange with Greil Marcus | publisher = Rock Critics Archives | date = 2002-03-12 | url = http://rockcriticsarchives.com/interviews/greilmarcus/01.html | accessdate = 2008-04-15}} The review was intended to [[parody]] the "[[supergroup (music)|supergroup]]" trend then taking place ([[Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young]], [[Blind Faith]] and [[Led Zeppelin]]) and was also inspired by ''[[Great White Wonder]]'', a double album of unreleased Dylan recordings often credited as the first bootleg. Many readers, however, took the review seriously, despite its obvious jokes: *"Produced by [[Al Kooper]], the album was recorded with impeccable secrecy in a small town near the site of the original [[Hudson Bay]] Colony in [[Canada]]." *"The LP opens with an eighteen-minute version of '[[Season of the Witch (song)|Season of the Witch]]' (lead vocal by Dylan, on which he does a superb imitation of early [[Donovan]]). The cut is highlighted by an amazing jam between bass and piano, both played by Paul McCartney." *"Dylan shines on Side Three, displaying his new deep bass voice, with '[[Duke of Earl]]'." *"Paul showcases his favorite song, '[[My Mammy|Mammy]]', and while his performance is virtually indistinguishable from [[Eddie Fisher (singer)|Eddie Fisher]]'s version, it is still very powerful, evocative, and indeed, stunning. And they say a white boy can’t sing the [[blues]]!" *"It can truly be said that this album is more than a way of life; it is life."T.M. Christian (Greil Marcus), "The Masked Marauders," The Rolling Stone Record Review, compiled by the editors of ''Rolling Stone'' (New York: Pocket Books, 1971), p. 392. ==Recording sessions and contract== Enquiries began pouring into ''Rolling Stone'' regarding the album’s availability, not only from fans and retailers, but reportedly from the artists' managers, [[Allen Klein]] ([[Beatles]] and [[Rolling Stones]]) and [[Albert Grossman]] (Dylan).{{Cite news | last = Gleason | first = Ralph J. | author-link = Ralph J. Gleason | title = On the Town | publisher = ''San Francisco Chronicle'' | date = October 18, 1969 | url = http://www.stones.at/stones/vinyl/lpdiv/masked.htm | accessdate = 2008-04-15}}. The response sparked part two of the put-on: the album itself. Marcus and ''Rolling Stone'' editor [[Langdon Winner]] recruited the Cleanliness and Godliness Skiffle Band, a [[Berkeley, California]], group which had an album the previous year on [[Vanguard Records]] and played frequently at [[San Francisco]]’s [[The Fillmore|Fillmore]] and [[Avalon Ballroom|Avalon]] ballrooms.{{cite web | last = Dodsworth | first = Fred | title = At 35, the Freight Finds Its Future in Tradition | work = The Berkeley Daily Planet | date = 2003-06-06 | url = http://www.berkeleydailyplanet.com/issue/2003-06-06/article/16764 | accessdate = 2008-04-15}} The group initially recorded three of the songs cited in the review: the ''[[Nashville Skyline]]''-inspired [[instrumental]] "Cow Pie", Jagger doing "I Can’t Get No Nookie" (deemed "an instant classic"), and Dylan’s "Duke of Earl".{{citation | title = The Masked Marauders - The Complete Deity Recordings | publisher = Rhino Records }} After the [[songs]] aired on San Francisco and [[Los Angeles]] [[radio stations]] – from tapes Marcus supplied – the pranksters began looking for a [[major label]] to produce an album. Several recording companies expressed an interest, but Warner Bros. won the production rights, offering a $15,000 advance plus its considerable promotional power. In November 1969, Warner released ''The Masked Marauders'' as a single LP on its newly created Deity label. The album, which sold more than 100,000 copies, spent 12 weeks on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' album chart, peaking at No. 114. The single "Cow Pie" appeared on the [[Bubbling Under the Hot 100]] chart at No. 123 for one week on November 29, 1969. ==Original and follow-up releases== Tipping off buyers to the [[joke]] (albeit after they had purchased the album), Warner inserted the ''Rolling Stone'' review as well as a ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' column by critic [[Ralph J. Gleason]], a co-founder of ''Rolling Stone''. Gleason found it incredible anyone believed the review and declared the gag a "delightful bit of instant [[mythology]]." The closing track, "Saturday Night at the Cow Palace," also made clear the album was all in fun. The track featured a riotous [[monologue]] by a record buyer so indignant at being taken in by the hoax that he vows, "When I get through with those people at Deity Records, I’ll have them walking out of the building in barrels." The album’s [[liner notes]], penned by "T.M. Christian," also offered its share of clues, most notably the line: "In a world of sham, the Masked Marauders, bless their hearts, are the genuine article."T.M. Christian (Greil Marcus), "Masked Marauder" liner notes, Rhino Records, Claremont, California, 1969. In 2003, [[Rhino Records]], under its Handmade label, remastered the album, releasing a numbered edition of 2,000 copies entitled ''The Masked Marauders - The Complete Deity Recordings''. The lineup of songs is the same as on the original LP, except for [[bonus tracks]] of the [[monaural]] single, "I Can’t Get No Nookie" b/w "Cow Pie". The title of the re-issue posed yet another joke: the album was Deity’s only recording. As one of its contributions to the [[Parody|spoof]], Warner created Deity under its Reprise subsidiary to match the name of the non-existent record company credited in the ''Rolling Stone'' review. == Media coverage == The story of ''The Masked Marauders'' hoax was featured in an April 5, 2013, segment of the TV program ''[[Rock Center with Brian Williams]]''.{{cite news|title=Scoop: Rock Center with Brian Williams on NBC - Today, April 5, 2013|url=http://tv.broadwayworld.com/article/Scoop-ROCK-CENTER-WITH-BRIAN-WILLIAMS-on-NBC-Today-April-5-2013-20130404|newspaper=Broadway World|date=April 5, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Shattuck|first=Kathryn|title=What’s On Friday|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/05/arts/television/whats-on-friday.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 5, 2013}} ==Track listing== ===Side one=== # "I Can't Get No Nookie" (The Masked Marauders) – 5:29 #* Features vocals by a Mick Jagger impersonator. This track is sometimes mislabeled as an outtake from the Rolling Stones' ''[[Jamming with Edward!]]'' sessions. # "[[Duke of Earl]]" (E. Dixon, E. Edwards, B. Williams) – 3:21 #* Also briefly incorporates "Blue Moon" (Rodgers, Hart). #* Features vocals by a Bob Dylan impersonator. # "Cow Pie" (The Masked Marauders) – 2:18 #* Mainly instrumental, but features brief vocals by a Bob Dylan impersonator. # "I Am [[The Japanese Sandman]] (Rang Tang Ding Dong)" (A. Williams) – 3:45 # "The Book Of Love" (W. Davis, C. Patrick, G. Malone) – 2:21 #* Also briefly incorporates "Norwegian Wood" (J. Lennon, P. McCartney). #* The group's John Lennon impersonator is heard speaking briefly at the end of this track. ===Side two=== #
  • "Later" (W. Davis, C. Patrick, G. Malone) – 1:11 #* A continuation of "The Book Of Love". # "More or Less Hudson's Bay Again" (The Masked Marauders) – 3:31 #* Features vocals by a Bob Dylan impersonator. # "[[Season of the Witch (song)|Season of the Witch]]" (Donovan Leitch) – 10:13 #* Features vocals by the Mick Jagger and Bob Dylan impersonators. # "Saturday Night at the Cow Palace" (The Masked Marauders) – 1:30 #* A spoken monologue atop a piano rendition of "Cow Pie," with a disgruntled voice profanely denouncing the album as a rip-off. ===CD bonus tracks=== #
  • "I Can't Get No Nookie" (The Masked Marauders) – 5:02 (Monaural) # "Cow Pie" (The Masked Marauders) – 2:18 (Monaural) ==Musicians== As listed on the Rhino Handmade CD release: *[[Langdon Winner]]: Piano and Backing Vocals *Annie "Dynamite" Johnson: Vocals and Percussion *Phil Marsh: Vocals and Guitar *Brian Voorheis: Vocals, Guitar and Harmonica *Vic Smith: Bass *Anna Rizzo: Drums *Mark "The Fox" Voorheis: Drums and Vocals on "Saturday Night at the Cow Palace" *Gary Salzman: Lap Steel *Luke Wienecke: Organ *Allen Chance: Vocals on "More or Less Hudson's Bay Again" == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.snopes.com/music/artists/masked.asp Snopes article] *[http://www.stones.at/stones/vinyl/lpdiv/masked.htm San Francisco Chronicle article] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7aXvQ6cg9Vs] YouTube clip for I Can't Get No Nookie * [http://www.chickenonaunicycle.com/Cleanliness%20and%20Godliness.htm Cleanliness and Godliness Skiffle Band Family Tree] {{Bob Dylan}} {{John Lennon}} {{Paul McCartney}} {{Mick Jagger}} {{The Rolling Stones}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Masked Marauders}} [[Category:Musical hoaxes]] [[Category:1969 albums]]

{{Infobox recurring event | name = Top Marques Monaco | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = Top Marques Monaco logo-200px.jpg | logo_alt = Top Marques Monaco logo, consisting of the event name in all-caps serif font, white text on black, with "Monaco" smaller and in gold | logo_caption = | logo_size = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | status = Active | genre = Supercar show and luxury fair | frequency = Annually | venue = [[Grimaldi Forum]]{{cite web|last1=Hortail|first1=Philippe|title=Top Marques Monaco, le salon VIP|url=http://www.largus.fr/actualite-automobile/top-marques-monaco-le-salon-vip-708369.html|website=L'argus.fr|accessdate=17 September 2015|date=20 April 2011}}([https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=[[:fr:Top Marques Monaco&prev=search]] translated from the French by Google Translate]) | location = 10 Avenue Princesse Grace
98000 [[Monaco]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|44|37|N|7|25|54|E|type:event|display=inline,title}} | country =Monaco | founder_name = Lawrie Lewis | years_active = 2004–present | first = {{start date|2004|04|22}}–{{start date|2004|04|25}} | dates = | begins = {{start date|2018|04|19}} | ends = {{start date|2018|04|22}} | last = {{start date|2017|04|20}}–{{end date|2017|04|23}} | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = 35,000 (2014) | capacity = | area = | budget = | activity = | leader_name = | patron = [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]] | organised = | filing = | people = Manoj Bairstow, managing director;
Mederic del Monaco, shareholder;
Steven Saltzman, shareholder{{cite web|title=Contact|website=TopMarquesMonaco.com|url=http://www.topmarquesmonaco.com/en/contact.html|accessdate=2017-09-17}} | member = | sponsor = | website = {{URL|TopMarquesMonaco.com}} | footnotes = }} '''Top Marques Monaco''' is an event that takes place annually at the [[Grimaldi Forum]] in the principality of [[Monaco]]. It features exhibitions by numerous purveyors of luxury aircraft, automobile, banking, boat, footwear, handbag, jewellery, real estate and wine products.{{cite web|title=Top Marques Monaco 2013 show gallery|url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/motor-shows/top-marques-monaco-2013-show-gallery|website=AutoCar.co.uk|accessdate=18 September 2015|date=20 April 2013}} One feature of the Top Marques Monaco that sets it apart from other automotive exhibitions is its use of the adjacent [[Formula 1]] [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]] racetrack to display cars in action{{cite web|last1=Hall|first1=Nick|title=The World's Most Exclusive Auto Show — Top Marques Monaco|url=http://www.motortrend.com/features/performance/1105_the_worlds_most_exclusive_auto_show_top_marques_monaco/viewall.html|website=MotorTrend.com|accessdate=17 September 2015|date=5 May 2011}} and conduct test drives.{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Scott|title=2014 Top Marques Monaco|url=http://senatus.net/event/2014-top-marques-monaco/|website=SENATUS.net|accessdate=17 September 2015|date=6 January 2014}} A quarter of the event's ticket sales are donated to [[Monaco Aide et Présence]], a charity established by Monaco's reigning [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Prince Albert]]. Manoj Bairstow took over as managing director of the company in 2012.http://www.topmarquesmonaco.com{{Not in citation|date=September 2017|reason=link goes to main page, where Bairstow is not mentioned}} == 2010 == Sales during the event totalled US$600 million (446 million euros). The entrance fee was 50 euros. == 2011 == At the four-day 2011 event, there were 42 automotive manufacturers exhibiting luxury vehicles, 13 manufacturers exhibiting luxury yachts and other boats, and 26 jewelry manufacturers exhibiting watches. Exhibitors included [[Bugatti]], [[Dartz]], [[Exagon Engineering]], [[Gillet]], [[GTA Motor]], [[Koenigsegg]], [[Noble Automotive]], [[Pagani (automobile)|Pagani]], and [[Peraves]]. Six cars made their European debuts, including the Conquest Knight XV [[SUV]] and the Keating ZKR. A hundred cars were on display, of which more than two dozen were available for test drives. The entrance fee was 50 euros. Attendance was 33,000 people from twelve countries. == 2013 == The four-day 2013 Top Marques Monaco featured six [[supercar]] debuts, including [[Abt Sportsline|ABT Sportsline]], [[Hamann Motorsport]], [[Mansory]], and [[Motoren Technik Mayer|MTM]], and exhibitions by over 150 companies.{{cite web|last1=Domijan|first1=Igor|title=Monaco 2013: Highlights by Igor Domijan|url=http://gtspirit.com/2013/04/21/monaco-2013-highlights-by-igor-domijan/|website=GTspirit.com|accessdate=17 September 2015|date=21 April 2013}} Supercars on display included the [[GTA Spano]], the [[Gumpert Apollo]], the Koenigsegg Hundra, the [[Mazzanti Evantra]], the Noble Automotive M600, the [[Roding Automobile]] Roadster, the Savage Rivale, the Soleil Motors Anadi, and the [[Vencer]] Sarthe. Other exhibitors included [[Aston Martin]], [[Bentley]], [[Ferrari]], [[Fisker Automotive|Fisker]], [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]], [[Lamborghini]], Pagani, [[Rolls-Royce Motor Cars|Rolls-Royce]], [[Ronn Motor Company]], Vintech, and [[Wiesmann]]. == 2014 == Running from 17–20 April,{{cite web|last1=Lathbury|first1=Claire|title=Selling the future|url=http://www.rivieratimes.com/index.php/monaco-article/items/selling-the-future.html|website=[[The Monaco Times]]|accessdate=18 September 2015|date=2 April 2014}} 2014's Top Marques Monaco was attended by [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Prince Albert]] of Monaco, [[Loris Capirossi]], and a total of more than 35,000 other attendees. Vehicles premiered included [[David Brown Automotive]]'s Speedback, [[Energica Motor Company]]'s [[Energica Ego|Ego 45]] motorcycle,{{cite press release|author=|title=Energica Ego 45 a Hit at Top Marques Monaco|url=http://www.motorcycle-usa.com/2014/05/article/energica-ego-45-a-hit-at-top-marques-monaco/|website=Motorcycle-USA.com|accessdate=17 September 2015|date=6 May 2014}} NanoFlowcell's [[Quant E|Quant e-Sportlimousine]], and [[W Motors]]'s Lykan HyperSport. Other vehicles on display included cars manufactured by Aston Martin, [[Audi]], [[BMW]], Bugatti, Ferrari, [[Hamann Motorsport]], [[Mazzanti Automobili]], [[Mercedes-Benz]], Pagani, [[Porsche]], [[Tesla Motors]], and [[Zenvo ST1|Zenvo]];{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Brad|title=Video: The Very Best Supercars From Monaco's Top Marques Weekend|url=http://gtspirit.com/2014/04/23/video-the-very-best-supercars-from-monacos-top-marques-weekend/|website=GTspirit.com|accessdate=18 September 2015|date=23 April 2014}} and the Energica Motor Company's Eco, Forza·G's Icaro and Demonio, and [[Mando Corporation|Mando]]'s Footloose e-bicycles. VIP ticket-holders had the opportunity to use a 3D virtual studio to try their hands at designing a supercar. Other exhibitors had jet-propelled hovercraft and powered surfboards on display. The entrance fee was 50 euros.{{cite web|last1=Fiala|first1=Jiri|title=Top Marques Monaco 2014: Přehlídka superluxusu|url=http://www.auto.cz/top-marques-monaco-2014-prehlidka-superluxusu-80888|website=Auto.cz|accessdate=18 September 2015|date=26 April 2014}} ([https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=cs&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.auto.cz%2Ftop-marques-monaco-2014-prehlidka-superluxusu-80888 translated from Czech by Google Translate]) == 2015 == Automotive exhibitors included BMW, Ferrari, Lamborghini, [[McLaren Automotive|McLaren]],{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Brad|title=2015 Top Marques Monaco Day 2 Highlights|url=http://gtspirit.com/2015/04/19/2015-top-marques-monaco-day-2-highlights/|website=CTspirit.com|accessdate=17 September 2015|date=19 April 2015}} Mercedes, Nimrod Performance, Porsche, Tesla and Zenvo.{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Brad|title=Top Marques Monaco 2015 Final Highlights|url=http://gtspirit.com/2015/04/26/top-marques-monaco-2015-final-highlights/|website=CTspirit.com|accessdate=17 September 2015|date=26 April 2015}} Larte Design's Tesla Model S and [[Toroidion]]'s 1MW{{cite web|title=Finnish electric supercar turns heads in Monaco|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/finnish_electric_supercar_turns_heads_in_monaco/7934502|work=YLE Uutiset [YLE News]|accessdate=18 September 2015|date=17 April 2015}} had their world premieres there, as did the [[AeroMobil s.r.o. AeroMobil|AeroMobil 3.0]], a [[Slovakia]]n-made road-legal vehicle that transforms into a [[light aircraft]].{{cite web|last1=Flis|first1=Robert|title=Aeromobil Flying Roadster Unveiled at Top Marques Monaco|url=http://www.therichest.com/luxury/auto/aeromobil-flying-roadster-unveiled-at-top-marques-monaco/|website=TheRichest.com|accessdate=18 September 2015|date=17 April 2015}} == 2016 == The theme of Top Marques Monaco 2016 was James Bond; supercars from the film ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]'', as well as an [[Aston Martin DB5]] as seen in ''Goldfinger'', were on display along with props from the franchise.{{Cite news|url=http://www.royalmonaco.net/2016/04/james-bond-revient-a-top-marques-monaco-james-bond-sera-de-retour-a-monaco-pour-la-premiere-fois-depuis-plus-de-vingt-ans-avec-un-et|title=James Bond Revient a Top Marques Monaco|last=|first=|date=2016-04-03|work=Royal Monaco Riviera|access-date=2017-09-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170917214120/http://www.royalmonaco.net/2016/04/james-bond-revient-a-top-marques-monaco-james-bond-sera-de-retour-a-monaco-pour-la-premiere-fois-depuis-plus-de-vingt-ans-avec-un-et|archive-date=2017-09-17|dead-url=yes|language=fr-FR|issn=2057-5076}} == 2017 == AeroMobil s.r.o. unveiled the production model of its [[AeroMobil s.r.o. AeroMobil|AeroMobil flying car]], announcing that it would begin taking pre-orders for the vehicle before the end of 2017.[http://www.koamtv.com/story/35199345/correction-monaco-flying-car-story Krivokapic, Milos, and Angela Charlton, "Correction: Monaco-Flying Car story," Associated Press, April 21, 2017, 9:22 AM EDT.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422134007/http://www.koamtv.com/story/35199345/correction-monaco-flying-car-story |date=April 22, 2017 }}[https://www.aeromobil.com/official-news/detail/aeromobil-unique-limited-edition-flying-car-launched-at-top-marques-show/ Anonymous, "AeroMobil, Unique Limited Edition Flying Car, Launched at Top Marques Show," aeromobil.com, April 20, 2017.] Other exhibitors, including Donkervoort D8 GTO-RS, Vanda Electrics Dendrobium, and Calafiore C10 had their world premieres. The [[Jean-Raymond Boulle|Jean Boulle Luxury Group]] announced that its patent-pending luxury diamond finish technology had been applied to a classic [[Pininfarina]]-styled [[Bentley]], the [[Bentley Azure]] exhibited that year. The Boulle Luxury Bentley Azure was unveiled by [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]] on 20 April at the official opening of Top Marques 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.topmarquesmonaco.com/en/top-marques-monaco-2017/exhibitors/boulle-luxury.html,01560|title=Jean Boulle Luxury Group unveils Classic Bentley Azure covered with 2 million gem diamond crystals to demonstrate its proprietary diamond finish|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hellomonaco.com/news/events-entertainments/top-marques-monaco-2017-flying-cars-and-drone-races/|title=For First time at the Grimaldi Forum, a Bentley covered completely in diamond paint|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/supercars-flying-vehicles-show-top-marques-monaco-134205259.html|title=Bentley Azure painted with two million diamonds from the Jean Boulle Luxury group,|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2017}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Trade fairs in Monaco]] [[Category:Auto shows]] [[Category:Boat shows]] [[Category:Fashion events]] [[Category:Wine-related events]] [[Category:Spring (season) events in Monaco]]

{{Infobox Magazine | name = | image_file = Veintitrés magazine cover.jpg | image_size = 180px | image_caption = | publisher = Manucorp, S.A. | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | total_circulation = 26,000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivc.org.ar/consulta?op=c&asociado_id=536|title=Datos del medio: Veintitrés|publisher=IVC}}</ref> | circulation_year = 2011 | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | country = Argentina | firstdate = 16 July 1998 | lastdate = | category = News | frequency = Weekly | editor = Diego Saraceni | editor_title = Director | website= [http://www.veintitres.com.ar/ ''Veintitrés''] }} '''''Veintitrés''''' (meaning ''Twenty-three'' in English) is a weekly [[news magazine]] published in [[Argentina]].
==History== The magazine was established in 1998 as XXI, in reference both to the upcoming century, and to Lanata's previous publication Página/12 (''21'' is ''12'' with the figures reversed), by [[Jorge Lanata]] and colleagues from the television news magazine, ''Día D'': [[Adolfo Castelo]], Olga Gatti, Claudio Martínez, Jorge Repiso, [[Ernesto Tenembaum]], and Marcelo Zlotogwiazda. Advertised as ''La revista del siglo que viene'' ("The magazine for the century to come"). Later, as people would keep calling it "siglo veintiuno" rather than just ''veintiuno'' ("Twenty-one," ) it changed its name to "Veintiuno". It later appeared as ''Veintidós'' (Twenty-two), and from 2000 onward by its current title, meaning twenty-three.
Much as Lanata's successful news daily, ''[[Página/12]]'', had done, ''Veintitrés'' adopted a format of bold headlines and graphics, as well as a [[muck-raking]] editorial style. Its target audience is the middle and high socioeconomic classes and professionals, government officials, and students.<ref>{{cite journal|author2=Joaquin Barnoya|author1=Javier Saimovici|title=Argentina: “non-smokers’ dictatorship”|journal=Tob Control|date=2004|volume=13|issue=6|url=http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/13/1/6.1.full.html|accessdate=19 June 2016}}</ref> The magazine also became known for its [[gag gift]]s, chosen in allusion to the news story of the day. Lanata sold a 75% stake in 2001 to investigative journalist Ernesto Tenenbaum,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nuevosperiodistas.com.ar/entrevistasread_pro.asp?id=7|title=Entrevista|publisher=Nuevos Periodistas}}</ref> after which ''Veintitrés'' was directed by Guillermo Alfieri; Alfieri left the magazine in 2008 to join Lanata's short-lived ''[[Crítica de la Argentina]]''. ''Veintitrés'' was purchased in 2008 by Sergio Szpolski, who, in turn, sold a 50% stake in Grupo Veintitrés (which also published ''[[Newsweek Argentina]]'', ''[[Tiempo Argentino]]'', among other periodicals, and operates Channel 23) to Matías Garfunkel in 2011. The media group's broadcasters and publications established themselves as some of the most supportive of [[Kirchnerism]] among Argentina's diverse media.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ideascasiprincipales.wordpress.com/2011/02/26/la-venta-de-los-medios-k-de-szpolski-ver-versiones/|title=Garfunkel Partners adquirió el 50% del Grupo Veintitrés|work=Ideas Casi Principales}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.veintitres.com.ar/ Official website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Veintitres}} [[Category:1998 establishments in Argentina]] [[Category:Argentine news magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1998]] [[Category:Spanish-language magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]]

revision.text:
{{italicstitle}} '''''Vivat! Vivat Regina!''''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|v|aɪ|v|æ|t|_|r|ɪ|ˈ|dʒ|aɪ|n|ə}} is a play written by [[Robert Bolt]].<ref>London Playbill Picadilly Theatre </ref> It debuted at [[Chichester Festival Theatre|Chichester]] in 1970 and later at the [[Piccadilly Theatre]] London. Principal actors were [[Sarah Miles]] and [[Eileen Atkins]]. The play was directed by [[Peter Dews (director)|Peter Dews]] and designed by [[Carl Toms]]. [[Richard Pearson (actor)|Richard Pearson]] also played a role.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theatricalia.com/play/4wq/vivat-vivat-regina/production/paw|title=Production of Vivat! Vivat Regina! - Theatricalia|website=theatricalia.com}}</ref> Later, the play had a successful run on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/vivat--vivat-regina-3637|title=Vivat! Vivat Regina! – Broadway Play – Original - IBDB|first=The Broadway|last=League|website=www.ibdb.com}}</ref>
The play tells the story of two rival [[monarch]]s who never met: Scotland's [[Mary, Queen of Scots]] and her cousin, Queen [[Elizabeth I of England]]. The play's title is [[Latin]] for "Long live! Long live the Queen!", and is taken from the [[I was glad#Acclamation|acclamation]] at the [[Coronation of the British monarch|Coronation Service]].
The first act contrasts the personalities of the two monarchs, as they engage in a battle of wiles. Elizabeth is portrayed as a woman who has given up on love and family in order to maintain a firm grasp on power, while Mary is portrayed as a reckless, impulsive woman ready to risk power for love.
The second act concentrates on Mary's term as a prisoner of Elizabeth, during which time she reflected on her own pending execution.
[[Eileen Atkins]] played Elizabeth in the play's British and American debuts. Bolt's wife [[Sarah Miles]] played Mary in the original British production, while [[Claire Bloom]] played Mary in the play's Broadway debut. A 1985 off-Broadway revival featured [[Geraldine Page]] as Elizabeth and Sabra Jones as Mary.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/03/17/theater/theater-geraldine-page-in-bolt-s-vivat-regina.html|title=THEATER: GERALDINE PAGE IN BOLT'S 'VIVAT REGINA!'|first=Mel|last=Gussow|date=17 March 1985|publisher=|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref>
The play was, next to ''[[A Man for All Seasons]]'', Bolt's most successful stage production, receiving several Tony nominations for its Broadway production.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/vivat--vivat-regina-3637/#awards|title=Vivat! Vivat Regina! – Broadway Play – Original - IBDB|first=The Broadway|last=League|website=www.ibdb.com}}</ref>

{{short description|Opera by Jonathan Harvey}} {{For|the 2012 documentary film|Wagner's Dream}} {{Italic title}} '''''Wagner Dream''''' is an [[opera]] by [[Jonathan Harvey (composer)|Jonathan Harvey]], premiered in 2007, to a libretto by [[Jean-Claude Carrière]], which intertwines events on the last day of the life of [[Richard Wagner]] with elements from a fragmentary opera sketch by Wagner himself, ''[[Die Sieger]]'' (''The Victors''). ==Background== ''Die Sieger'' was drafted between 1856 and 1858, at a period when Wagner had become greatly interested in [[Buddhism]]. It is based on legends which Wagner discovered in [[Eugène Burnouf]]'s 1844 ''Introduction to the History of Buddhism''. Wagner planned a production of this work for 1870 in his programme for King [[Ludwig II of Bavaria]] but never progressed it – (however elements of the story persist in his opera ''[[Parsifal]]'').[http://www.monsalvat.no/sieger.htm Prose Sketch for ''Die Sieger''] in ''Monsalvat – the Parsifal Pages'', retrieved 28 January 2012 Harvey described some of the processes he used in creating ''Wagner Dream''. These include the use of a [[French horn]] and a [[sampling (music)|sampled]] [[trombone]] playing deep notes at the opera's commencement, representing boat [[siren (noisemaker)|siren]]s on the [[Grand Canal (Venice)|Grand Canal]]. The composer also visited [[Chamonix]] to sample a [[thunder]]clap, used to preface an argument between Wagner and his wife.Harvey (2008), 38–39, 41 ==Narrative structure and scoring== The story tells of the love of the outcast [[chandala]] Prakriti for the monk [[Ananda]]. Although both are ostracized by the other monks, [[Buddha]] permits their chaste union and allows Prakriti to join the monastic community. ''Wagner Dream'' intersperses the Prakriti/Ananda story with the events surrounding Wagner's death in [[Venice]]. As Wagner dies from a heart attack, he recalls the opera he never completed. Whilst the "Indian" roles are all sung, the members of the Wagner household, including his wife [[Cosima Wagner|Cosima]] and the [[soprano]] [[Carrie Pringle]] (with whom it has been alleged that Wagner had his last love affair) are spoken roles.Andrew Clements, ''[https://www.theguardian.com/music/live/story/0,,2071182,00.html%20wagner%20dream Wagner Dream]'', ''[[The Guardian]]'', 3 May 2007 (retrieved 28 January 2012) The score uses [[electronic music]] as well as an ensemble of 24 musicians.Faber Music News, (northern) Autumn 2007 ==Premiere and performance history== The opera was premiered at the [[Grand Théâtre de Luxembourg]] in April 2007, prior to a run at the [[Westergasfabriek]], Amsterdam, in a production by [[Pierre Audi]] for [[De Nederlandse Opera]], which commissioned the work. Its British premiere took place at the [[Barbican Centre]] as a concert performance in London on 29 January 2012.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/orchestras/events/908 ''Wagner Dream''], [[BBC]] website (retrieved 28 January 2012) The first British staged performance was given on 6 June 2013 in the [[Wales Millennium Centre]] [[Cardiff]] by [[Welsh National Opera]], directed by Pierre Audi.''Wagner Dream'' programme book, WNO Summer 2013. In this production, German was used for the spoken text while the Buddhist characters sang in [[Pali]]. In a programme note, WNO's artistic director, [[David Pountney]], stated that this change was discussed with Jonathan Harvey with the aim of "seeking to enhance and clarify the cultural dialogue which is the centrepiece of (Harvey's) opera"."A note about language", in ''Wagner Dream'' programme book, p.52. ==Roles== {| class="wikitable" !Role ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast, 28 April 2007, Grand Théâtre, Luxembourg
